The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
The State Chancellor's Office recently advised that the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District will experience reduced funding in the amount of $1,998,000 as a result of lower than anticipated student enrollment fees and property tax revenues for FY 2011-2012.  This is in addition to the $4,271,000 that was cut as part of the State's adopted budget (6.21% workload reduction) and the $1,385,000 that was cut in January when the triggers were pulled (Tier 1 and Tier 2) bringing a total reduction of $7,654,000 to the San/Jose Evergreen Community College District.
	 
Adoption of this resolution would call on the Governor and the State legislature to address the unexpected cut of $1,998,000 and support a backfill of the lost revenue.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 022812-1 supporting the backfill of student enrollment fees and property tax revenues shortfall.

items.item_details:
As part of the Budget Study Session, the Board of Trustees reviewed a set of budget principles and budget assumptions, and provided direction to staff on budget solution strategies designed to provide the policy framework for the Chancellor and Executive Staff in the development of a District Budget for the 2012-2013 fiscal year.  In particular, items reviewed include:
	 
Background
 
Each year staff strives to refine and improve on our budget development and planning processes.  The goal is to maintain transparency, provide a constant flow of information and as needed refine projections, strategies and processes designed to meet the challenge of ongoing budget shortfalls while adhering to budget principles to maintain a balanced budget.  Budget planning this year has proven to be even more difficult than in years past because mid-year cuts and truly unexpected cuts (i.e. “February Surprise”) have made it near impossible to plan responsibly.  The approach established by the Chancellor has been to expand the Executive Team to include the college Vice Presidents in budget reviews and discussions.  This expanded group has met several times since January in order to understand the magnitude of the problem, identify future strategies and weigh the implications of proposed actions on the needs of students. 
 
This document is designed to:
Reaffirm existing budget principles previously adopted by the Board.
Confirm budget assumptions.
Review proposed strategies.
Establish support for those “time sensitive” strategies that, if considered, require immediate implementation.
Finally, it is important to note that the magnitude of the problem can only be resolved through the use of multiple strategies.  In addition, given our responsive and flexible processes, these strategies can and should be refined, revised and amended as more information becomes available. 
 
Budget Principles
The Board will provide a policy framework and the Chancellor and staff will execute/implement specific reductions and revenue enhancement strategies within that framework.
Rebalancing strategies must consider a “student centered” perspective to mitigate to the extent possible the impact on students.
Rebalancing strategies must address the findings and concerns regarding fiscal solvency identified by the Accreditation Commission.
Rebalancing strategies must be immediate, becoming effective for the 2012-2013 fiscal year.  Multiple solutions will be adopted that will impact revenue and expenditures, will be on-going as multi-year solutions and include one-time adjustments as part of the solution package.
Budget Assumptions
The district will continue to maintain a 7% general fund reserve.
The budget will use budget assumptions as presented in the Quarterly Reports. 
The budget will assume that the State Tax Measure scheduled for November, 2012 passes.
The majority of budget rebalancing strategies must effectively increase revenue, and reduce expenditures in a permanent on-going way.  Additional adjustments will be necessary that are one-time only for the 2012-2013 budget. 
The budget will recognize that figures will change as new information becomes available, including year-end carryover, student enrollment fee deficits, property tax deficits, redevelopment agency revenue, basic aid relief, and other unforeseen budget adjustments and uncertainties.
Multiple Possible Rebalancing Strategies (in no particular order)
Resource Development Strategies
Revenue generation strategies that may include expansion of the non-resident program, facility rental expansion, foundation and grant fund raising, etc.  
May include reinvigorating the bookstore and cafeteria revenue programs.  
Long term strategies may include public/private ventures and a possible parcel tax initiative.  
Enrollment Management - Target to Funded Cap 
Maximize fall/spring course offerings – reduce summer school program* – reduce intersession.
Anticipate 5.56% potential FTES reduction if State Tax Measure Fails (Nov. 2012).
Establish fixed Adjunct Faculty Budgets based on defined productivity ratios-unit allocation system.
Reduce General Fund Support for “Restricted Programs”
Reduce/Eliminate Fund 10 backfill for Categorical Programs
Raise Parking Fees for Fall and Spring from $40 up to $50 and from $8 up to $25 for summer.*
Apply parking permit fees and/or daily parking fees to staff (requires collective bargaining).
Increase daily parking fees from $2 to $3.
Defund Position Vacancies
Eliminate budgets and realize savings for vacant positions, retirements, resignations and reorganizations.** 
Maximize Use of Other Funds
Bookstore Fund Balance transfer (one-time dollars).
Workforce Institute Fund Balance support (one-time dollars).
Charge direct staff costs to grants, categoricals, auxiliary, and/or bond funds, as appropriate.
Maximize indirect cost allowance associated with grants.
Collective Bargaining
Contractual items will be negotiated with respective labor representatives as appropriate.  These strategies may include the work calendar, compensation; benefit restructuring and other areas identified through the bargaining process.
 
*time sensitive item – the timeline for preparing the summer schedule begins in March; in addition, early warning to students about the summer session will enable them to plan appropriately.
 
**Given significant reductions in existing staff undertaken last year, it is clear that the District cannot undertake “reduction in force” as a primary strategy.  The preferred approach is not to fill current vacancies for the 2012-2013 budget year, and to subsequently revisit this matter.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the budget principles, approve the budget assumptions and provide direction on multiple rebalancing strategies that will guide the 2012-2013 Budget Development Process.

items.item_details:
In 2004 the Legislature passed AB 1417 (Pacheco), Accountability Reporting for Community Colleges.  The bill established a framework for annual evaluation of community colleges using six agreed-upon measures of success.  The law requires that an annual report be submitted to the State Chancellor's Office and mandates that a subsequent presentation be provided to the governing boards to ensure that a public conversation and review regarding the outcomes and progress made along each of the measures is conducted.
	 
In direct response to previous requests by this Board for quantifiable measures of programs within our District, this presentation will be used to inform our conversation about the "Student Success Agenda."

items.item_details:
At the January 10-12, 2012 meeting of the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges, Commissioners reviewed the reports resulting from the accreditation visit to our District completed on November 8-9, 2011. Subsequent to this review, Dr. Barbara Beno, communicated the results of the Commission deliberations through letters addressed to Presidents Kavalier and Yong and to Chancellor Cepeda (see attached).   Both presidents have issued messages to their college constituents summarizing the findings and identifying the next steps in the process.  Copies of the three letters are attached to this item.
	 
As we anticipated, the Commission elected to maintain current status for both colleges, acting to “continue Evergreen Valley College on Warning and San Jose City College on Probation and to require Follow-Up Reports from both colleges by October 15, 2012.”  And while this is a bit disheartening here is the good news:
	 
We avoided a further decline to the next level of sanction (i.e. “show cause” for City and “probation” for EVC.)  This action was certainly an option for the Commission had they determined that little or no efforts had been undertaken to address their concerns.  The opposite was true; in fact, Dr. Beno stated that:
	 
 “While acknowledging the significant work that has been accomplished by both colleges and the District to begin to address recommendations and resolve deficiencies, the Commission has chosen to wait until all work is completed and deficiencies resolved, before taking action to remove sanctions.” 
	 
In addition, as the letters indicate many of the concerns have been removed from consideration and a reduced but critical list is now in place.  The Commission expects us to address fully the remaining recommendations in advance of their next visit, which is now scheduled for October 2012. It is important to note that addressing these recommendations is now the number one priority of our colleges and our entire district. 
	 
This item will provide a summary of the remaining recommendations for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College, in addition to three remaining "Shared" or districtwide recommendations.

items.item_details:
At its December 13, 2011, Governing Board Meeting, the Board of Trustees appointed Maria Fuentes, Mayra Cruz, Jeffrey Lease to the Board Committee on Student Success.
	 
The Board Committee on Student Success is charged with working with staff to review the proposed ACCT Student Success Policy Draft and consider these recommendations in conjunction with previous Board discussion and action on CLASS (California Leadership Alliance for Student Success,) the Board’s own Workplan and Priorities and the proposed recommendations of the Board of Governors’ Student Success Task Force recommendations. The specific charge of the committee is to compare, contrast and analyze these various sources and to present a set of policy constructs that is consonant with the Board’s direction as adopted in its Workplan.
	 
The Committee scheduled its first meeting on February 21 and designated Trustee Cruz as chair.  This item will present a brief summary of the meeting and proposed next steps.

items.item_details:
On November 8, 2011, the Board of Trustees formally approved a workplan, including projects and deadlines to address ten priority areas that emerged directly from the Board's Self Evaluation Process.  The ten priority areas were further subdivided in two parts:  Workplan A- included priority areas in direct response to Accreditation findings also known as the "Shared Recommendations"  and Workplan B, which  focused on additional issues areas that emerged from the evaluation survey.  
		 
On January 24, the Board received the first update using the "Workplan Dashboard" to provide a quick "at-a-glance" review.  At this same meeting it was agreed the Board's Committee on Self Evaluation; namely, Trustees Cruz, Okamura and Lease, should remain in place in order to a) provide monthly "dashboard" updates; and b) restart the annual board self evaluation review cycle.  Trustee Okamura accepted responsibility for providing the monthly dashboard updates. 
		 
The purpose of this item is to present this month's update.
